pullRequest.title: feat(datastore) Trigger hub events during sync
pullRequest.bodyText:
Issue #, if available:
Description of changes:
Trigger the following events during initial sync:

syncQueriesStarted: triggered when the sync process starts.
syncQueriesReady: triggered when all models have been sync'd
modelSynced: triggered for each individual model upon completion of the sync process for each model. Includes the sync type (FULL or DELTA), model name and number of records added, updates and deleted during the sync.

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that my contribution is made under the terms of the Apache 2.0 license.

commit.message: feat(datastore) Trigger hub events during sync

nodes.bodyText: Should we also remove REMOTE_SYNC_STARTED and REMOTE_SYNC_STOPPED as part of this? Right now, I think we have some duplicative code. A good goal would be to align the events to iOS and Android. In so doing, that means we have to rename/remove the events we have, that already provide a similar functionality.

I'm not sure what "sync queries ready" means, just from the name. Is this a good name?
The Javadoc is the same on L63 and L68 so I think at least one needs to be updated.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -52,7 +52,22 @@
     /**
      * The remote synchonization processes stopped.
      */
-    REMOTE_SYNC_STOPPED("remote_sync_stopped");
+    REMOTE_SYNC_STOPPED("remote_sync_stopped"),
+
+    /**
+     * The DataStore is about to start the Sync Queries.
+     */
+    SYNC_QUERIES_STARTED("syncQueriesStarted"),
+
+    /**
+     * All models have been synced.
+     */
+    SYNC_QUERIES_READY("syncQueriesReady"),

nodes.bodyText: One says model (singular) and one says models (plural). From the Javadoc, it looks like it means the plural form. If that's so, can we name this ALL_MODELS_SYCNED? This probably means going back to the cross-platform design doc and making sure the other guys do likewise. Or, if JS already has these publicly documented and live, we could at least align some better names with iOS.

+    MODEL_SYNCED("modelSynced");

nodes.bodyText:
Since we have the observer pattern here, I don't think you even need to put this in the SyncProcessor at all, do you? You could have this be like a SyncMetricsPublisher.java or a SyncMetricsObserver.java, and then cleanly separate all of this logic into its own little place.
Overall though, I'm worry about how long hydrate() is getting, here. Any approaches you can think of to break this apart into some smaller bits would probably useful, towards keeping the code clear. -- Keep in mind, the reader expects hydrate() to be mostly about populating data, not broadcasting events.
The other benefit to breaking out a separate observer class is that you will no longer have SyncProcessor depending on the LocalStorageAdapter. I don't think I ever completely got there, but you can se several mid-level utilities like the VersionRepository, etc., which abstract away the LocalStorageAdapter from the sync processor. All in all, I think the LocalStorageAdapter is a fairly low level detail for the sync processor and -- where possible -- it would be best to avoid direct dependency on it.

nodes.bodyText: Or, alternately, you could just use your enum type? getSyncType()? The way you have it is fine too.

Since you'll send these back to the customer, be sure that all of your event structures are:

Immutable;
Implement equals, toString, and hashCode
If applicable, implementing Comparable might be appropriate as well?

nodes.bodyText:
If you use the array primitive, be sure to do an Array.copy on the input, so that your DTO won't be effected if the input hcanges. https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/Arrays.html#copyOf(U[],%20int,%20java.lang.Class)
same deal on this one -- equals, toString, and hashCode, please

commit.message: Checkstyle fixes and other minor tweaks
Add equals, hashCode, toString to ModelSyncedEvent
Cleaned up old remote sync events

nodes.bodyText: This seems to be a frivolous construct. Isn't this just equivalent to using modelProvider.models() directly?

It gets assigned here, but where is it used? Do you have behavior in the constructor? If so, can you move it to start() and stop() methods, and keep the constructor only for dependency wiring?
Other thought: it would be kinda nice if this could be syncProcessor.addObserver(new SyncMtericsObserver()), or if the syncProcessor just managed this thing internally, itself._

To self document it, you could express this as int expectedModelCount = Arrays.asList(EventObject1.class, EventObject2.class).size().

nodes.bodyText: Ah crumbs. I guess HubAccumulator should have taken long, in hindsight, huh?
Can we do BlogOwner.class.getSimpleName() for these case statements, instead of string literal?
I discuss a ForEach utility below that may make sense, if we have to pull this same trick more than a time or two.
Oh duh, or wait -- update. Can you just reuse the ModelSyncMetrics as a pojo to store these immediate values?
Does this get sent back to user? Does it need to be public, with equals/hashCode/toString and field accessors?

What implications does this have on testability, if you inline Amplify.Hub? Should we instead snake a hub instance in through the constructor? That way, you could provide a mock in test, if you needed to?
I forget why we put this in the publish arg... it seemed like a good idea at the time?

See other comments about ForEach. This one returns String[] though instead of List<String>. I guess we'd have to standardize. Oh, or like ForEach.inArray, ForEach.inList, etc. Could do multiple collection types
Is this a dead store variable? Doesn't look like syncableModels gets used.
Is this dead store, too?
Does it make sense for the key to be the constrained type, DataStoreItemChange.TYPE, instead of just String?

Is there anyway we can avoid having these callbacks?
The Completable is already an asynchronous signal. Now, this method has two different async signals that have different lifecycles. It's a bit to handle, conceptually.
One possible option, if you need to observe save/deletes on the datastore, is the observe() method on the LocalStorageAdapter? Hopefully that can be setup internally, without effecting the Merger's contract?

nodes.bodyText: The previousStatus.transitionTo(newStatus) is a little bit hidden, currently. I'd put it on its own naked line just so people can see it visibly and make note of the behavioral part. Hidden inside the publish, it could easily be glanced over as "oh just publish some static stuff..."

commit.message: Change call site format for transitionTo
